##    Introduction

First things first: let‚Äôs get one thing straight, I am NOT an expert, nor am I a computational scientist or a professional generative artist. While knowledge of some ‚Äúmath things‚Äù can be super helpful, you don‚Äôt need to know complex computational mathematics to make Rtistry (aRt). Granted, if you enjoy and want to create aRt similar to the works of [Thomas Lin Pedersen](https://www.data-imaginist.com/art) and [Danielle Navarro](https://art.djnavarro.net/), then maybe you do! But as a beginner, it‚Äôs important to remember that your Rtistry is your work and opportunity to learn, grow as an R programmer, and create pieces you can be proud of. Remember that your aRt is an expression of you and no one else and that there is no "right" way to do Rtistry. One of the things I love most about creating aRt is the fact that I don‚Äôt have to get anything ‚Äúright.‚Äù For those of us who use R for work/educational endeavors, we must ensure that our statistics, programming, and literally everything else is correct. Creating Rtistry can provide your mind with not only a creative outlet but a way to still practice programming in R in a low-stress environment where things don‚Äôt have to be "right."


###   Why Rtistry?


Some people may think of the concept of creating aRt and may think it‚Äôs a waste of time since no analyses are performed. If you think that way, you have every right to that opinion. What I can share with you, though, is why I personally love creating Rtistry:

+   Gives my brain a rest from ‚Äúreal work‚Äù
+   Allows me to practice programming skills in a stress-free environment
+   Gives me satisfaction from flexing my creative skills
+   Gives me more content for professional portfolios


##    Ethics


While using others‚Äô work as inspiration to give yourself ideas is OK, you should always strive to create something of your own merit. Just like in the physical art world, you may also find that some aRtists may not want to share their process or code with you. Those that are new to Rtistry may be shocked by this. Some newbies may even think that creators come off as standoffish or rude if they decline to share their work. This could be because of how supportive the R community usually is and how we are always seemingly ready to share our code.


One thing to remember is that a creator could decline to share their code for many reasons. Those decisions are personal and left up to each aRtist on an individual basis. The aRtists that do exceptionally unique work will have usually put a lot of effort and hours into their pieces to a point where it may even feel proprietary. Some aRtists choose to sell their outputs not only because they have made something truly personal to them, but because they‚Äôve also made something unique that probably hasn‚Äôt existed before.


When you find an Rtistry piece that appeals to you, you could try to understand what‚Äôs happening behind the scenes instead of asking directly for the code. It tends to be a fun challenge to figure out what‚Äôs happening yourself. It‚Äôs a lot of work, yes, but I am willing to bet that if you use R for professional work, the work and study you do to figure out how to create your pieces will benefit you in the long run.


What you choose to do with the pieces you create is entirely up to you. Some aRtists get their work printed for sale or personal use, some look into selling them as [Non-fungible Tokens (NFTs)](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Non-fungible_token) and some literally save their output and never save their code, completely erasing its footprint in a cathartic click of a button. Whatever you do, always give credit where credit is due; don‚Äôt assume that everyone is willing to share their code with you (but if they do, always express gratitude and give credit for the assist); and try to be ethical in everything that you do.

##    Geoms


If you want to start making data aRt in ggplot, having some knowledge on ggplot geoms will prove to be very useful. If you‚Äôve ever participated in a [#tidytuesday challenge](https://github.com/rfordatascience/tidytuesday) or have made visuals in [ggplot](https://ggplot2.tidyverse.org/index.html), you‚Äôre probably familiar with them. The key to using geoms to create your aRt is to understand what type of data is expected for each geom. Some basic ones to start with are:

+   [`geom_point()`](https://ggplot2.tidyverse.org/reference/geom_point.html)
+   [`geom_line()` & `geom_path()`](https://ggplot2.tidyverse.org/reference/geom_path.html)
+   [`geom_segment()` & `geom_curve()`](https://ggplot2.tidyverse.org/reference/geom_segment.html)
+   [`geom_polygon()`](https://ggplot2.tidyverse.org/reference/geom_polygon.html)


There is no limit to which geoms you can use for aRt in ggplot. Your only barrier would be not having your data formatted appropriately for whichever geom you wish to use. For example, if you want to use `geom_segment()` you'd need to know that this function expects four different data points (`x`, `xend`, `y`, and `yend`). The geom functions will usually do a good job of throwing an error and letting you know if you're missing any data points. If you‚Äôre interested, you can always learn more about ggplot with the official [cheat sheet](https://github.com/rstudio/cheatsheets/blob/master/data-visualization-2.1.pdf) or [book](https://ggplot2-book.org/).

##    Making and Applying (Rtistry) aRt Data to Geoms


If the geoms are the instruments in your toolkit, the data is your ink/paint. The data you provide to each geom will produce visuals on ggplot‚Äôs coordinate system. Thinking about it broadly, to make one point on a basic ggplot you need at least one x and one y value:

```{r codesnip1, echo = TRUE, fig.cap="A Single Point", fig.align="center"}
library(tidyverse) #For everything data====

## Example 1: Data Frame====
single_point <- tibble(x=0, y=0)

## Example 1 ggplot====
single_point %>%
  ggplot(aes(x = x, y = y))+
  geom_point()

```

<br>


Having several x and y points is what will get you some shapes, lines, and other things:

```{r codesnip2, fig.cap="Random Lines", fig.align="center", echo = TRUE}
## Example 2: Data Frame====
random_lines <- tibble(x = sample(1:500, 50),
                       y = 1:50)

## Example 2: ggplot====
random_lines %>% 
  ggplot(aes(x=x, y=y, xend = median(x), yend = median(y)))+
  geom_segment()

```

<br>

The magic happens when you can start viewing the grid differently. When you begin to understand the relationship the values in a data frame have with the ggplot coordinate system, it becomes easier to realize what data is needed to create your desired output. For example, if you want to create abstract art, you might practice making datasets with randomized values. If you want to make intentional pieces, you might spend time studying the axes of the ggplot and determine what range of values you need to make the figures you want. The process of creating data for Rtistry and applying them to geoms can be as simple or complicated as your creativity allows. Let's just go over a simple example with a basic square.

We know that a square consists of four lines. Each line has a start and endpoint. So, we at least need to make four points on our plot. Since each point consists of two values (x and y), we‚Äôll need eight values in total. Four x points and four y points.

<br>

```{r codesnip3, echo = TRUE}
## Example 3: Data Frame====
square <- tibble(x = c(0,5,5,0), 
                 y = c(0,0,5,5),
                 labels = 1:4)

```

<br>

Because we want to make a shape that‚Äôs closed (so we could potentially fill it with color), we‚Äôd want to use `geom_polygon()`. You might be thinking ‚Äúwhy not use `geom_line()` instead?‚Äù because a square consists of four lines, but let‚Äôs look at that. If we make a data set of the points that are supposed to make a square but then pass it through to `geom_line()` or `geom_path()` functions, we get these instead:

<br>

```{r codesnip4, fig.cap="\"Square\" made with geom_line()" , fig.align="center", echo = TRUE}
## Example 3: Geom_line() ggplot====
square %>%
  ggplot(aes(x = x,
             y = y,
             label = labels))+
  geom_line()+
  geom_label()+
  coord_equal()

```


```{r codesnip5, fig.cap="\"Square\" made with geom_path()", fig.align="center", echo = TRUE}
## Example 4: Geom_path() ggplot====
square %>%
  ggplot(aes(x = x,
             y = y,
             label = labels))+
  geom_path()+
  geom_label()+
  coord_equal()

```

<br>

**geom_line()** looks this way because it plots points in order by the x axis. Try to take a moment to compare the data and the result and understand why it came to be.


**geom_path()** looks closer to a square! But we‚Äôre missing a side! This is because `geom_path()` doesn‚Äôt create a fully closed shape by default. `geom_path()` is the same as `geom_line()` except it plots points in the order in which it appears in the dataset.

Now let‚Äôs use **geom_polygon()** with the same data set:

<br>
```{r codesnip6, fig.cap="\"Square\" made with geom_polygon()", fig.align="center", echo = TRUE}
# Example 5: Geom_polygon ggplot====
square %>%
  ggplot(aes(x = x,
             y = y,
             label = labels))+
  geom_polygon()+
  geom_label()+
  coord_equal()

```

<br>

There we go; An actual square. `geom_polygon()` is similar to how `geom_path()`‚Äôs process of drawing lines works. The only difference is that the start and endpoints are automatically connected and you can add a ‚Äúfill‚Äù aesthetic to your new shape. By default, ggplot does fill the square. You can set `fill = NA` to make it empty, but remember to set a color argument if you want to see the ‚Äúborder‚Äù of the polygon make its shape:

<br>

```{r codesnip7, fig.cap="Square - geom_polygon() ggplot with no fill", fig.align="center", echo = TRUE}
# Example 6: Geom_Polygon ggplot with no fill====
square %>%
  ggplot(aes(x = x,
             y = y,
             label = labels))+
  geom_polygon(fill = NA, color = "black")+
  geom_label()+
  coord_equal()

```

<br>

As a beginner, it‚Äôs tempting to try and make every cool idea that comes to you, but it‚Äôs a good idea to spend time with these basics first. You can explore creating aRt data sets with formulas you may be interested in or with any of the ‚Äúnon-visual‚Äù functions I‚Äôll discuss later in the article. Once you feel comfortable creating aRt datasets and applying them to geoms, you might be able to find cool and unexpected ways to plot things!

<br>

##    Aesthetics


The next important set of basics to learn about is ggplot aesthetics. We've already used aesthetics in the previous section's examples, but let's think about them a bit more. Each base ggplot and geom function comes with available aesthetics. If you‚Äôve ever made a ggplot visualization and changed any colors, shapes, etc., you‚Äôre already familiar with the foundations needed to start customizing the look/style of your work. 


There‚Äôs two ways you can map aesthetics onto your visuals:


  1) The [`aes()`](https://ggplot2.tidyverse.org/reference/aes.html) function in your initial ggplot() function
  2) Directly into the geom function you wish to change. 


As you explore what you want to do and how you want to style your data, you may find that you prefer one way over the other. If you get stuck on this part, take some time to think about what you‚Äôd like to see on the grid and then think logically about which method would make sense.


For example, if you have a variable that contains [hex color codes](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Web_colors) attached to each row in a dataset, it may make sense to set up the aesthetic in the `aes()` function since it‚Äôs already connected to the data. If you have a circumstance where you only want one geom to be one color, or you want to map a different data set of aesthetics to the geom, you can put it into the actual function.

**A word of caution though, if you want to add values from a different dataset, make sure they have the same number of rows as the initial data set that you are piping into the initial ggplot‚Äôs function.** If they don‚Äôt match up and you don‚Äôt set the `inherit.aes` argument to **`FALSE`** in the geom, you‚Äôll get an error. There are ways to use different data sets in addition to the initial one used at the beginning of your ggplot call. I‚Äôll touch on this in the layering section of this article. For now, let‚Äôs take a quick look into setting aesthetics in our square example:


Let‚Äôs say we want to color our square purple and make colored dots on each point of the square. Because the polygon will only be filled with one color, we can set that in the `geom_polygon()` call. If we add a color variable to our data set with individual hex color codes attached to each observation, we can place it in the `aes()` function and get our desired output with the following code:

<br>

```{r codesnip8, fig.cap="Square- geom_polygon() with colored points", fig.align="center", echo = TRUE}
# Example 7: Geom_Polygon ggplot with colored points====

## Example 7: Data Frame====
square_color_points <- tibble(x = c(0,5,5,0),
                 y = c(0,0,5,5),
                 colors = c("#c0d943","#027337","#d12017","#000a96"))
                 
## Example 7: Geom_Polygon ggplot with colored points====
square_color_points %>%
  ggplot(aes(x = x,
             y = y))+
  geom_polygon(fill = "#4b1980")+
  geom_point(color = square_color_points$colors)+
  coord_equal()

```

<br>

We can also change multiple aesthetics at once. We can change the size of our points too:

<br>

```{r codesnip9, fig.cap="Square - geom_polygon() with randomly sized points", fig.align="center", echo = TRUE}
# Example 8: Geom_Polygon ggplot with colored points and Random Sizes====
square_color_points %>%
  ggplot(aes(x = x,
             y = y))+
  geom_polygon(fill = "#4b1980")+
  geom_point(color = square_color_points$colors,
             size = sample(1:20, nrow(square_color_points)))+
  coord_equal()

```

<br>

As you get more comfortable with aesthetics, you will find that there may be different ways to explore these settings programmatically using various ideas or functions. One of the greatest things about Rtistry is realizing that you may already have the programming knowledge necessary to use these basic components to create amazing things. 


At the end of the day, if you find yourself stuck on how to do something, it may be helpful to search google, the [RStudio Community forums](https://community.rstudio.com/), or even [Stack Overflow](https://stackoverflow.com/questions/tagged/r) for the answers to programming questions that may help you piece together your Rtistry. In my experience, I‚Äôve always had the best results when I take a moment to stop and think about what I am asking R to do programmatically. R doesn‚Äôt know that I want to randomize colors for an image, but it will know if I want it to pick random hex color values from a vector by using the `sample()` function. I can then apply that result to an aesthetic option and get the desired output.


If I were googling for the answer to this example, I wouldn‚Äôt type *‚Äúhow to randomize colors of geom_point()‚Äù* but instead I‚Äôd type *‚Äúhow to randomly pick values from a vector in R programming.‚Äù* It may take a little bit to understand this thought process, but you are programming after all, so try to approach any troubleshooting as if you were coding for ‚Äúactual work‚Äù.

<br>

##    Using ‚Äúnon-visual‚Äù Functions For Your Visuals


The first time I realized that you could pass additional functions into aesthetic options - my mind was blown! I did not realize that anything other than a string of a hex color could go into a color aesthetic in ggplot. My mind was so stuck on how I learned to code for ggplot. It was also bound by the fact that I never needed to think about setting any options outside of regular color ‚Äústrings‚Äù for my everyday work. Take the random data below. We could change the colors of these random points by applying some random colors...

<br>

```{r codesnip10, fig.cap="Ggplot of randomized points", fig.align="center", echo = TRUE}
## Example 9: Data Frame====
random_points <- tibble(x = 1:100,
                        y = sample(1:100))

## Example 9: ggplot of randomized points====
random_points %>%
  ggplot(aes(x=x, y=y))+
  geom_point()

```

<br>

```{r codesnip11, fig.cap="Ggplot of randomized points with randomized colors", fig.align="center", echo = TRUE}
## Example 10: ggplot of randomized points with randomized colors====
random_points %>%
  ggplot(aes(x=x, y=y))+
  geom_point(color = sample(RColorBrewer::brewer.pal(5,"PRGn"), nrow(random_points), replace = TRUE))

```

<br>

...Or by placing a logical function in the color aesthetic for `geom_point()`. For example, we can tell R that we only want to apply randomized colors to any data points that have a y value that‚Äôs less than 50, otherwise observations with a y value that‚Äôs greater than or equal to 50 will just be colored black with an `ifelse()` function:

<br>

```{r codesnip12, fig.cap="Ggplot of randomized points with randomized colors and logic applied", fig.align="center", echo = TRUE}
# Example 11: ggplot of randomized points with randomized colors and logic applied====
random_points %>%
  ggplot(aes(x=x, y=y))+
  geom_point(color = ifelse(random_points$y < 50,
                            sample(RColorBrewer::brewer.pal(5,"PRGn"), nrow(random_points), replace = TRUE),
                            "black"))

```

<br>

Since there is no limit to the different types of functions a user can make, the possibilities of different functions that can be added to aesthetics seems endless. A few functions that might help you not only in aesthetics, but working with your data prepping are listed below to get you started:

<br>

+   [`sample()`](https://www.rdocumentation.org/packages/base/versions/3.6.2/topics/sample) ‚Äì Randomly take a sample from elements of an object
+   [`rep()`](https://www.rdocumentation.org/packages/base/versions/3.6.2/topics/rep) ‚Äì Replicate (repeat) elements in a vector or list
+   [`seq()`](https://www.rdocumentation.org/packages/base/versions/3.6.2/topics/seq) ‚Äì Generates numeric sequences
+   [`runif()`](https://www.rdocumentation.org/packages/compositions/versions/2.0-2/topics/runif) ‚Äì Returns a random composition of numbers with a uniform distribution
+   [`dnorm()` & `rnorm()`](https://www.rdocumentation.org/packages/stats/versions/3.6.2/topics/Normal) ‚Äì Creates a normal density distribution and random normal distribution of numbers
+   [Trigonometric Functions (`cospi()`,`cos()`,`sin()`, etc.)](https://www.rdocumentation.org/packages/base/versions/3.6.2/topics/Trig) ‚Äì Results in the computation of various trigonometric functions.
+   [`Crossing()`, `expand()`, `nesting()`](https://tidyr.tidyverse.org/reference/expand.html) ‚Äì Tidyr functions that expand data frames to include possible combinations of values.
+   [Control-flow constructs (`while`, `repeat`,`if`, `for`, etc.)](https://www.rdocumentation.org/packages/base/versions/3.6.2/topics/Control) ‚Äì Can be used to create iterations, patterns, and functions of your own.
+   [Apply](https://www.rdocumentation.org/packages/base/versions/3.6.2/topics/apply) family functions ([`lapply`, `sapply`, etc.](https://www.rdocumentation.org/packages/base/versions/3.6.2/topics/lapply)) ‚Äì Can be used to apply functions on different objects like matrices, vectors, or lists.

<br>

Remember that this is not an exhaustive list, but just a taste of some commonly used functions to hopefully get the gears turning about different ways you can manipulate your ggplot aesthetics and actual Rtistry data.

##    Layering


The last basic concept in this post is ggplot layering. Adding layers with the [`layer()`](https://ggplot2.tidyverse.org/reference/layer.html) function or even annotations with the [`annotate()`](https://ggplot2.tidyverse.org/reference/annotate.html) function is very useful as it allows the user to add different layers of data. You can also achieve this by adding geom functions as you would normally, but if you ever want to add geoms that pull from different data sources this way, you need to set the `inherit.aes` argument to `FALSE`, as this will then allow the ggplot to build without error.


These multiple ways of layering allows for endless possibilities as piecing together an image this way provides a bit more flexibility. Take the two datasets below. One is intended to just create some lines with `geom_segment()`, and the other is intended to just create circles in between each line with `geom_point()`. Because we want 4 lines and 3 circles, the amount of data needed to map these things don‚Äôt match up. We can tell this on a quick glance by seeing that the number of rows in each data set don‚Äôt match up:

<br>

```{r codesnip13, fig.cap="Circles_data and Lines_data logic check", fig.align="center", echo = TRUE}
## Example 12: Lines_data Data Frame====
Lines_data <-  tibble(x = rep(1, 4),
                      xend = rep(5, 4),
                      y = seq(0,6, by = 2),
                      yend = y )

## Example 12: Circles_data Data Frame====
Circles_data <- tibble(x = 3,
                       y = unique(abs(seq(0,6, by = 2) - 1)),
                       size = 1:3)

##Logic Check: Do these dataframes have the same number of row?##
nrow(Lines_data) == nrow(Circles_data)

```

<br>

If we try to add these together by just using a geom function ,`geom_point()`, and supplying the `Circles_data` directly into `geom_point()` without typing `inherit.aes = FALSE`, the console will throw an error:

<br>

```{r codesnip14, results='hide', fig.align="center", error = TRUE, echo = TRUE, fig.show='hide'}

## Example 12: Lines_data and Circles_data error====
Lines_data %>%
  ggplot(aes(x=x, y=y, xend = xend, yend = yend))+
  geom_segment(size = 15)+
  geom_point(data = Circles_data, aes(x=x, y=y, size = size)) 

```

<br>

This error tells you that object `xend` is not found. This is because we are attempting to override the data frame that is attached to the entire ggplot (`Lines_data`) with `Circles_data` now and `xend` definitely does not exist in `Circles_data` and therefore ‚Äúcan‚Äôt be found.‚Äù To fix this specific example and get the desired results, simply add `inherit.aes = FALSE` into the `geom_point()` function. If desired, you also could just move the aesthetics for `Lines_data` into the `geom_segment()` function but as you will find, there are multiple ways to get to the same result. For this example though, we'll just add the `inherit.aes` argument to `geom_point()`.

<br>

```{r codesnip15, fig.cap="ggplot of Lines_data and Circles_data layered together with the addition of geom_point()", fig.align="center", echo = TRUE}
## Example 12: Adding Lines_data and Circles_data together with inherit.aes in geom====

Lines_data %>%
  ggplot(aes(x=x, y=y, xend = xend, yend = yend))+
  geom_segment(size = 15)+
  geom_point(data = Circles_data, aes(x=x, y=y, size = size), inherit.aes = FALSE)

```

<br>

We can also use the `layer()` function or the `annotate()` function to achieve similar results. Both methods are used in the example below:

<br>

```{r codesnip16, fig.cap="ggplot of Lines_data and Circles_data layered together with the layer() function", fig.align="center", echo = TRUE}

# Example 13: Adding Lines_data and Circles_data together with layer function====
Lines_data %>%
  ggplot(aes(x=x, y=y, xend = xend, yend = yend))+
  geom_segment(size = 15)+
  layer(geom = "point",
        data = Circles_data,
        stat = "identity",
        position = "identity",
        mapping = aes(x=x, y=y, size = size),
        inherit.aes = FALSE)

```

<br>

```{r codesnip17, fig.cap="ggplot of Lines_data and Circles_data layered together with the annotate() function", fig.align="center", echo = TRUE}
# Example 14: Adding Lines_data and Circles_data together with annotate function====
Lines_data %>%
  ggplot(aes(x=x, y=y, xend = xend, yend = yend))+
  geom_segment(size = 15)+
  annotate(geom = "point",
           x= Circles_data$x, 
           y= Circles_data$y, 
           size = Circles_data$size)

```

<br>

Both functions produce similar images. The `layer()` and `annotate()` functions have their own pros and cons based on what you‚Äôd like to do. As shown in the code snippets, each method of layering in ggplot is similar but has its own differences that may be favored in certain situations. I‚Äôd encourage you to read and explore these methods of layering a bit more, and to see what works best to execute your ideas.

<br>

##    Planet Quad ‚Äì aRt Example

<br>
<img src="images/planetquad.png"  style = "max-width:100%;" alt="Planet Quad - Rtistry - Four different colored planets in outer space made in the R programming language on a 2 x 2 grid">
<figcaption><i><center>Planet Quad</center></i></figcaption>
<br>

Now that we‚Äôve gone over some technical basics, let‚Äôs look at two Rtistry examples I‚Äôve created. The first is Planet Quad. The creation of Planet Quad demonstrates how we can utilize other packages like [patchwork](https://patchwork.data-imaginist.com/index.html) and [cowplot](https://wilkelab.org/cowplot/index.html) to create our own Rtisrty. Let‚Äôs break this down step-by-step.

Each layer in ggplot is built on top of each other in the order in which it appears in the code. For this image, that means we want the space/stars background to be **behind** our planets- so we can start with that **first**. 

We want four different plots with a similar design in different colors, so we can start by creating a named vector of the background colors we want to use. I always use hex colors, but you can use whatever format you‚Äôd like. I'll name mine `Space_colors`:

<br>

```{r codesnip18,  echo = TRUE}
# Library Load-In====
library(tidyverse) # For everything data
library(cowplot) # For placing plots on top of each other easily with ggdraw and draw_image
library(patchwork) # For packaging up the plots in the final image

# Star Backgrounds====

## Making four different stars "backgrounds" with four different colors====
Space_colors <- c("Topleft"="#000000",
                  "Topright"="#130321",
                  "Bottomleft"="#330500",
                  "Bottomright"="#8a4500")

```

<br>

Next, we want to create the data for the stars in our backgrounds. Because I want the image to look pretty filled in, I‚Äôll apply the `crossing()` function to the data in this `tibble` that I‚Äôll name stars:

<br>

```{r codesnip19,  echo = TRUE}
# Making a data set that will be used to create all star backgrounds====
stars <- tibble(crossing(x = seq(1,2000,100),
                         y = seq(1,2000,100)))

```

<br>

Next, we want to make a list because we‚Äôll run iterations of our `stars` dataset through a ggplot call that will also iterate through our vector Space_colors. This will result in a list of four similar plots that all have a different color scheme. We‚Äôll name this list `All_stars` and name the plots inside of the list to make it easier to track each plot as our session continues:

<br>

```{r codesnip20,  echo = TRUE}
## Making the list to hold the "space" plots====
All_stars <- list()

## Iterating through the "space_colors" to make four different plots====
for(i in seq_along(Space_colors)){
  
  All_stars[[i]] <- stars %>%
    ggplot(aes(x = x, y = y))+
    geom_jitter(size = sample(c(.02,.04,.06,.8),nrow(stars), replace = TRUE), color = "white")+
    theme_void()+
    theme(plot.background = element_rect(fill = Space_colors[i], color = "#ffffff", size = 6)) 
}

## Naming the plots just to help keep track of what's going where====
names(All_stars) <- names(Space_colors)

```

<br>

Now we can check and look at one of our plots by typing All_stars$Topleft in the console to verify that it looks like what we were expecting:

```{r codesnip21, fig.cap="The \"Topleft\" image in the All_stars list. A ggplot of the stars data", fig.align="center", echo = TRUE}

All_stars$Topleft
```

<br>

Now, we can work on our planets. The planets are actually just a [`geom_density2d_filled()`](https://ggplot2.tidyverse.org/reference/geom_density_2d.html) plot that will go through four iterations of the planet data set with its coordinate system set to [`coord_polar()`](https://ggplot2.tidyverse.org/reference/coord_polar.html. Just like we did for the stars data, we also want four very similar plots with different colors. Again, we can make a similar function to create a list of these plots. We just need to generate four different iterations of the data set and pick some colors for the planet surfaces. Let‚Äôs start with picking color palettes for planets and different colors for the border lines of each planet. We can place each palette into a list called `Planet_colors` and each border color into a vector called `Planet_borders`:

<br>

```{r codesnip22, echo = TRUE}
# Planet Creations====
## Setting the color palettes for each planet quad====
Planet_colors <- list("Topleft" = c("#194157","#008dd7","#085b88","#26925e","#095c88"),
                      "Topright" = c("#480463","#392242","#1e0329","#bf9232","#120b17"),
                      "Bottomleft" = c("#47322d","#6b1c09","#a30000","#6b1d09","#851205"),
                      "Bottomright" = c("#c7a602","#998523","#ba690d","#755b3d","#dbab39"))

## Setting the colors of each planet's borders====
Planet_borders <- c("Topright" = "#333333",
                    "Topright" = "#120b17",
                    "Bottomleft" = "#260f09",
                    "Bottomright" = "#5c523a")

```



We‚Äôll create some randomly sampled data to draw out our planets to encourage some weirdness in its final presentation. We‚Äôll name the dataset planet:

<br>

```{r codesnip23, echo = TRUE}
# Making a dataset that will be used to create all the planets====
planet <- tibble(crossing(x = sample(1:1000,100, replace = TRUE),
               y = sample(1:2000, 100, replace = TRUE)))

```

<br>

Now we‚Äôll create our list, named All_planets, that will be filled with our four different planets after it runs through our for-loop:

<br>

```{r codesnip24, echo = TRUE}
## Making the list to hold the "planet" plots====
All_planets <- list()

## Iterating through the "planet_colors" to make four different planet plots====
for(i in seq_along(Planet_colors)){
  
  All_planets[[i]] <- planet %>%
    ggplot(aes(x = x, y = y))+
    scale_fill_manual(values = sample(Planet_colors[[i]],100, replace = TRUE))+ #100 is just a arbitrary "safe" number I picked. geom_density does background calcs to create levels that varies based on data.
    geom_density2d_filled(color = Planet_borders[i], size = 2)+
    coord_polar(clip = "on")+
    theme_void()+
    theme(legend.position = "none")
}

## Naming the plots just to help keep track of what's going where====
names(All_planets) <- names(Planet_colors)

```

<br>

All these plots are now in our list `All_planets`. We can peek at one by typing `All_planets$Bottomright` into the console. Because a seed hasn‚Äôt been set anywhere, yours may look different than mine and that‚Äôs all right!

```{r codesnip25, fig.cap="The \"Bottomright\" image in the All_stars list. A ggplot of the stars data", fig.align="center", echo = TRUE}

All_planets$Bottomright

```

<br>

Now we can save all these planet plots as images out into the directory so we can load them right back in as [png files](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Portable_Network_Graphics). Please note that if you are following along, you may have to alter the directory to avoid errors as this directory is located within my [Data_aRt GitHub repo](https://github.com/Meghansaha/Data_Art/tree/master/creations/Collages/Planet Quad) in my Planet Quad project file.

<br>

```{r codesnip26, echo = TRUE}

# Saving Planets into the directory====
for(i in seq_along(All_planets)){
  
ggsave(paste0("planets/",
              names(All_planets)[i],
              "_planet.png"),
       All_planets[[i]],
       bg = "transparent", 
       device = "png")
}

```

<br>
<br>
<img src="images/snip1.png"  style = "width:100%;" alt="A snapshot of the processed PNG files in my personal working directory locally.">
<figcaption><i><center>A snapshot of the processed PNG files in my personal working directory locally.</center></i></figcaption>
<br>

Next, we need to bring the processed png files back into the environment. We can do this with the [png package](http://www.rforge.net/png/index.html). Because I‚Äôm only using this once, I chose to call in the [`readPNG()`](https://www.rdocumentation.org/packages/png/versions/0.1-7/topics/readPNG) function directly from the package instead of loading the package itself. We‚Äôll store the images in a list called `Planet_PNGs`.

<br>

```{r codesnip27, echo = TRUE}
# Loading Planets back into the environment as PNGs====
Planet_PNGs <- list()

for(i in seq_along(All_planets)){
  
Planet_PNGs[[i]] <- png::readPNG(paste0("planets/",
                                        names(All_planets)[i],
                                        "_planet.png"))
}

## Setting names to keep track of the planets====
names(Planet_PNGs) <- names(All_planets)

```

<br>

Now that we have png files, we can place these ‚Äúon top‚Äù of our star backgrounds we made earlier using the [`ggdraw()`](https://www.rdocumentation.org/packages/cowplot/versions/1.1.1/topics/ggdraw) and [`draw_image()`](https://www.rdocumentation.org/packages/cowplot/versions/1.1.1/topics/draw_image) functions from the cowplot package with for-loops. This time, we‚Äôll store them in a list called `Combined_plots`:

<br>

```{r codesnip28, echo = TRUE}
# Combining both the stars and planets to create four plots in total====
Combined_plots <- list()

for(i in seq_along(All_planets)){
  
  Combined_plots[[i]] <- ggdraw(All_stars[[i]]) +
                                  draw_image(Planet_PNGs[[i]])
}

## Setting names to keep track of the plots===
names(Combined_plots) <- names(Planet_PNGs)

```

<br>

Just like before, we can take a peek at any of the plots in the Combined_plots list to make sure it looks as expected. I‚Äôll use `Combined_plots$Bottomleft` in the console to see:

```{r codesnip29, fig.cap="The stars and planet plots combined", fig.align="center", echo = TRUE}

Combined_plots$Bottomleft

```

<br>

Looking good! Almost done! Now we can [`pluck()`](https://purrr.tidyverse.org/reference/pluck.html) each of our plots out and save them to individual objects! Because there‚Äôs only four of them, I‚Äôll just copy and paste that code because this is Rtistry and it's totally OK to be lazy. It‚Äôs your work. It‚Äôs your aRt . Do what you want!

<br>

```{r codesnip30, echo = TRUE}
## Plucking out all the individual plots===
Topleft <- Combined_plots %>% pluck("Topleft")
Topright <- Combined_plots %>% pluck("Topright")
Bottomright <- Combined_plots %>% pluck("Bottomright")
Bottomleft <- Combined_plots %>% pluck("Bottomleft")

```

<br>

Finally, we use [pacthwork‚Äôs layout syntax](https://patchwork.data-imaginist.com/articles/guides/layout.html) to combine these plots into one image:

<br>

```{r codesnip31, fig.cap="Planet Quad - Finished", fig.align="center", echo = TRUE}
# Final output construction with patchwork functions====
Planet_Quad <- (Topleft + Topright) / (Bottomleft + Bottomright)

# View the piece#
Planet_Quad

```

<br>

And voila! We have our finished piece! I‚Äôve noticed that sometimes patchwork may render in some borders around these images if [`ggsave()`](https://ggplot2.tidyverse.org/reference/ggsave.html) is used. In these cases, I just export using the Export button in the RStudio IDE.

<br>

##    Rainbow Rose ‚Äì aRt Example

<br>
<img src="images/rainbowrose.png"  style = "max-width:100%;" alt="An abstract image that was created in the R programming language. It shows a spiral on lines progressing from the center of the image towards the user with a progressive rainbow color palette on a black background">
<figcaption><i><center>Rainbow Rose</center></i></figcaption>
<br>

Finally, we‚Äôre at our last example! Rainbow Rose is an Rtistry piece that showcases one way trigonometric functions can be used to create cool results. This Rtistry piece was created from a beautiful accident when I mistyped some code while attempting to draw a circle from scratch in ggplot (yes, the [`geom_circle()`](https://ggforce.data-imaginist.com/reference/geom_circle.html) function from [ggforce](https://ggforce.data-imaginist.com/index.html) exists, but I was trying to improve my manual ggplot skills ü§∑üèæÔ∏è).

<br>

To start out, we need to set up some specifications that will alter how the data is plotted onto ggplot‚Äôs Cartesian coordinate system. This includes calculating the ‚Äútheta‚Äù(angles) of our intended circle, the number of divisions/data points we want in the dataset ‚Äú`n`‚Äù, and the radial setting we wish to have for the visual. Because we want to give an effect that starts from the center of the image, we set the radial setting, ‚Äú`r`‚Äù to a vector that spans from 1 to our ‚Äú`n`‚Äù value. 

<br>

```{r codesnip32,  echo = TRUE}
# Library Load-In====
library(tidyverse) # For everything data

# Setting parameters to prep ggplot to plot data in a "circular" fashion on the Cartesian coordinate system====

## Angle "slices"/ Sine/Cosine Frequency====
theta <- seq(0, 40*pi, length = 100) 

## Number of divisions/rows in the data wanted====
n <- 500

## "Radial" setting of the "circle" to create "n" different marks====
r = 1:n

```

<br>


Next, I‚Äôll use one of my favorite color palettes that I found for one of my [#TidyTuesday submissions](https://github.com/Meghansaha/TidyTuesday/blob/master/2021/9-14-21 Billboard_100/final_plot.png). I‚Äôll store them in a vector simply called ‚Äúcolors‚Äù:

<br>

```{r codesnip33,  echo = TRUE}
## Setting up the custom color palette====
colors <- c("#af3918", "#a21152", "#822b75","#612884","#154baf",
            "#0b82b9", "#277e9d","#488e35","#e3a934","#b2336a")

```

<br>

Now I‚Äôll create a simple data frame. I‚Äôll create my `x` and `y` variables using the [`cos()` and `sin()`](https://www.rdocumentation.org/packages/base/versions/3.6.2/topics/Trig) functions respectively:

<br>

```{r codesnip34,  echo = TRUE}
# Placing everything into a dataset====
data <- tibble(x = cos(theta)*r,
               y = sin(theta)*r)

```

<br>

Finally, we‚Äôll put everything together. Using `geom_path()` on this dataset and passing our colors vector into it creates our Rainbow Rose! 

<br>

```{r codesnip35, fig.cap="Rainbow Rose - Finished", fig.align="center", echo = TRUE}
# Pulling it all together====
Rainbow_Rose <- data %>%
  ggplot(aes(x = x, y = y, color = color))+
  geom_path(color = rep(colors, each = n/10), size = 1)+
  theme_void()+
  theme(legend.position = "none",
        panel.background = element_rect(fill = "black"))

# View it #
Rainbow_Rose

```

<br>

Mesmerizing! Play around and investigate the options used to try and understand how/why ggplot generated the data this way. 


For example, if we change `geom_path()` to `geom_line()` we get this:

<br>

```{r codesnip36, fig.cap="Rainbow Rose with geom_line() instead of geom_path()", fig.align="center"}
# Pulling it all together====
Rainbow_Rose <- data %>%
  ggplot(aes(x = x, y = y, color = color))+
  geom_line(color = rep(colors, each = n/10), size = 1)+
  theme_void()+
  theme(legend.position = "none",
        panel.background = element_rect(fill = "black"))

# View it #
Rainbow_Rose

```

<br>

Still pretty, but a completely different piece! Earlier in the article I mentioned the difference between `geom_path()` and `geom_line()` . Given their differences, does it make sense why this version looks this way? These are just some of the questions you can think about and ask yourself while you‚Äôre on your Rtistry journey!

<br>

##    There‚Äôs a Package for That


If you read all of this and still feel intimidated, that‚Äôs OK. You can still try to get into Rtistry with some of the following packages:
<br>


+   [aRtsy](https://github.com/koenderks/aRtsy) developed by [Koen Derks](https://github.com/koenderks)
  *‚ÄúAims to make generative aRt accessible to the general public in a straightforward and standardized manner‚Äù*


+   [Ambient](https://ambient.data-imaginist.com/) developed by [Thomas Lin Pedersen](https://github.com/thomasp85) and [Jordan Peck(FastNoise)](https://github.com/Auburn)
  *‚Äú...is a an R package that provides access to the FastNoise C++ library for generating noise.‚Äù*


+   [Ggvoroni](https://cran.r-project.org/web/packages/ggvoronoi/vignettes/ggvoronoi.html) developed by [Robert Garrett](https://github.com/garretrc) and Thomas Fisher 
  *‚ÄúWith ggvoronoi we can easily draw Voronoi diagram heatmaps, with help from packages deldir and ggplot2.‚Äù*


+   [contouR](https://github.com/Ijeamakaanyene/contouR) developed by [Ijeamaka Anyene](https://github.com/Ijeamakaanyene) 
  *‚ÄúcontouR is a package that is a wraparound for ggplot2::geom_contour() to use for generative aRt .‚Äù*


+   [Jasmines](https://github.com/djnavarro/jasmines) developed by [Danielle Navarro](https://github.com/djnavarro)
  *"The jasmines package is what Danielle uses to make a lot of her generative artwork with R. Internally it relies heavily on the ambient package, and you may need to install the developer version of ambient to make it work.‚Äù*


<br>

##    Final Remarks


This concludes The Tidy Trekker Intro to Data Art post! I really hope that those of you who are just trying to start out in Rtistry found this to be useful. While the basics content truly is basic, it really is a good chunk of the foundation needed to eventually progress into more complex generative aRt . Sometimes it can be difficult to disseminate the how-tos or guides for a creative process. As you saw with the Rainbow Rose piece, sometimes aRt can be created by accident. Those accidents can only be unique to you. The best way to improve your Rtistry skills is to just jump in and play. Use the time to zone out, relax, and engage with data in a way you may not have before.
